results.title: The Gift [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Sam Raimi, Gary Lucchesi, Tom Rosenberg, James Jacks and Columbia
results.brief_description: Set in Georgia, Cate Blanchett plays Annie Wilson, a young widow with three children to look after. Following an accident that kills her husband, she relies on her psychic visions to give the townsfolk clairvoyant readings regarding their relationships and love lives to earn a little extra money. Annie receives visits from Valerie (Hilary Swank) who is married to Donnie Barksdale (Keanu Reeves), a psychotic wife abuser who warns Annie not to talk to his wife again or he will hurt her and her children. She also has to contend with his taunts of her being a witch - a feeling that is echoed by some of the locals. When young socialite Jessica King (Katie Holmes) goes missing, the local police and her fiancee ask Annie for her help in finding the body and leading them to the murderer. Screenplay by Billy Bob Thornton.

results.title: Newsfront [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Richard Brennan, David Elfick and Palm Beach Pictures
results.brief_description: This is the dramatic story of the newsreel cameramen who lived and worked in Australia during the golden era of the newsreel from 1948 to 1956. Len Maguire is a top cameraman whose devotion to his work and loyalty to his company creates conflict with both his colleagues and the people he loves. Amy is a production assistant working in a predominantly male environment and Len’s brother, Frank, heads the Australian branch of an American newsreel company in competition with Len’s company.

results.title: Sex, guys and videotape
results.creator_credit: Martin Coombes, Mark Fitzgerald and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Elle McFeast (aka Lisbeth Gorr) presents this celebration of male sexuality with some of Australia’s pre-eminent males; Nick Giannopoulos, Greg Chappell, Lex Marinos, Mikey Robins, Hung Le, Rex Mossop, Mike Whitney, Ian Rogerson, Damien Lovelock, the Oarsome Foursome, Doug Mulray, Neil Murray, Piet Collins, Darren Baxter, Paul Hudson and Clive Robertson. Collectively, they discuss issues such as whether size really matters, self control, naming conventions, how they learnt about sex, the first time, condom wearing and what it feels like, what makes for sensational sex, performance anxiety and one night stands. Judith Lucy and Deborah Conway also contribute.

results.title: Looking for Alibrandi [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Kate Woods, Robyn Kershaw, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Premium Movie Partnership and AFFC
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by first time writer Melina Marchetta, “Looking for Alibrandi” is an affectionate look at three generations of strong willed Italian women, and the youngest member, Josie’s (Pia Miranda) attempt to break the family “curse”. 17 year old Josie lives with her single mother Christina (Greta Scacchi), is completing her HSC at an exclusive Sydney school on a scholarship, begrudgingly visiting her Nonna, defending the labels of “wog” and “bastard”, and longing after the lifestyle afforded to rich kids with both parents. When her father, Michael (Anthony La Paglia) enters their lives again, Josie confronts her mother and her Nonna about the rift between Christina and her father, and the animosity between mother and daughter to reveal secrets long since hidden. Josie must also make decisions about her future career and what her heart desires as she is torn between school captain John Barton (Matthew Newton) and public school boy Jacob (Kick Gurry). Between work, school, family and personal relationships, Josie discovers that life is filled with uncertainty and she is not the only one debilitated by the labels society ascribes. This was the first feature film effort for both director Woods and actor Miranda. Remarkably, the film was nominated and won several AFI awards, including best film, best supporting actress (Scacchi) and best performance by an actress in a leading role (Miranda).

results.title: Two hands [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Gregor Jordan, Marian MacGowan, Meridian Films and CML
results.brief_description: Set in Sydney’s King’s Cross, 19 year old Jimmy (Heath Ledger) finds himself in debt to a local gangster, Pando, played by perennial Australian actor Bryan Brown, when a simple job goes wrong. Jimmy’s life depends on his locating the $10,000 he has lost. As his scheme to replace the cash is played out, two street kids are enjoying a shopping spree with the original loot. The black humour of the film progressively darkens as the story unfolds. Rose Byrne co-stars as country girl, Alex, who becomes involved with Jimmy and his increasingly dire situation.

results.title: Black Hole Radio
results.material_description: Single-channel video, b&w and colour, audio
results.brief_description:
Over the past 20 years, filmmaker Jem Cohen has assembled a massive visual archive of Super 8 and 16mm by filming everyday images and experiences as he negotiates his way through the spaces of New York City. Filled with enigmatic glimpses, gestures and images seeming to come from half-remembered dreams, memories and snatches of conversations, this archive contains hints for unearthing the many secrets of contemporary metropolitan life.
In the mid 1990s Cohen encountered a series of advertisements for a New York City ‘Phone Confession Line’.To call in and confess was free; to listen cost money. Cohen acquired recordings of these taped confessions of murderous thoughts, desire and treachery, and used them to form the audio heartbeat of his video installation ‘Black Hole Radio’. Accompanied by ghostly Super 8 images filmed by the artist during his nocturnal wanderings, the installation reveals the anonymous lives and restless spirits that haunt the phonelines, televisions and sleepless nights of the city.
For this version of the installation, ACMI has worked with the artist to create a small confessional cell where images shimmer like paranoid hallucinations while disturbing whispers hang in mid-air, semi-publicly. The elusive images that linger on the edge of visual perception provide the evidence of Cohen’s investigation into the small confessed ‘crimes’: loving the wrong man, harbouring hatred or greed. Visitors leave ‘Black Hole Radio’ feeling the way they do when a shameful memory wakes them in the dead of night. Inside Cohen’s confessional, it is understood that it is both a privilege and a curse: to live as social beings and to know that isolation and forgetting can’t conceal the troubled heart of the city.
